title: Lennie and George were drifters in California during the Great Depression.
image: Lennie and George. Lennie is much bigger than George, who is small and wiry. They are standing in a field with a river in the background.
relate_to_story: Lennie and George are two migrant workers in California during the Great Depression. They share a dream of owning their own land, which symbolizes hope and friendship amidst the harsh realities of their lives.
quote: ‘Guys like us, that work on ranches, are the loneliest guys in the world. They got no family. They don’t belong no place…With us it ain’t like that. We got a future. We got somebody to talk to that gives a damn about us.’
quote_meaning: This quote emphasizes the theme of loneliness among migrant workers and the importance of George and Lennie's bond. It highlights their unique friendship in a world where most itinerant workers are isolated and disconnected.

critical_points.point: Explores the isolation of itinerant workers during the Depression.
Contrasts George and Lennie's companionship with the isolation of others.
George and Lennie's dream of owning a farm.
